document: This lecture covers recursive algorithms such as factorial and Fibonacci, the Merge Sort algorithm, and methods for solving recurrences like the Recursion‑Tree, Substitution, Master, and Iteration.

questions.question: The factorial of a number n can be computed using a recursive function that calls itself with argument n-1 until n equals 1.
In the recursive factorial implementation, the base case should return 0 instead of 1 for n == 1.
The iterative factorial implementation multiplies a running product by i as it decrements i from n down to 1.
The Fibonacci sequence starts with the values 0, 1, 1, 2, 3, … in this lecture.
In the recursive Fibonacci function shown, the base case returns 1 when n <= 2.
The iterative Fibonacci implementation uses an array f of length n+1 to store intermediate results.
Merge Sort stops recursing when the subarray has size greater than 2.
The Merge Sort algorithm sorts the left half, then sorts the right half, and finally merges them together.
In Merge Sort, the merge function creates a temporary array of size low+high to hold merged elements.
The recurrence T(n) = 2T(n/2) + O(n) correctly expresses the time for sorting an n‑element array using Merge Sort.
Solving a recurrence can be done by methods such as Recursion-Tree, Substitution, Master, and Iteration.
The Iteration method for solving recurrences expands the recurrence into a summation that is then evaluated.
In Example 1 of the lecture, the expression s(n) = n + s(n-1) leads to the solution s(n) = O(n^2).
When solving T(n)=2T(n/2)+c by the Iteration method, the number of levels in the recursion tree is log₂ n.
In Merge Sort's merge function, after merging all elements from both halves, the original array a is overwritten with values from the temporary array b.
The recurrence T(n)=2T(n/2)+c has solution Θ(n).
Merge Sort can be implemented in place with O(1) extra space if the merge step uses a linked‑list style merge.
